data.title: Pinkham Way waste plant application to be withdrawn by the North London Waste Authority
data.meta_description: Plans for the Pinkham Way waste plant will be withdrawn - but the site will still be used for sorting refuse.
data.text:
The North London Waste Authority (NLWA) has announced it will not move forward with plans for a waste disposal plant in Pinkham Way and will withdraw the application.

Campaign group the Pinkham Way Alliance fought against the plans for the plant, which would have been sited next to Muswell Hill Golf Course, arguing the facility would affect air quality and lead to increased traffic on the North Circular Road.

The NLWA says the Pinkham Way site is still in their plans as of a delivery, sorting and transfer point for recyclable material and other waste from local households.

Councillor Clyde Loakes, chair of NLWA said: “I hope today’s announcement on the future use of the Pinkham Way site will provide some further clarity and certainty for local people.

“They now know that subject to a successful planning application at the existing Edmonton site, there should be no residual waste treatment at Pinkham Way.”

The NLWA will continue with plans for a waste treatment plan in Edmonton, Enfield.
